G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody judgment upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a finding that the modification serves the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The requested modification aligns with the public policy of Massachusetts favoring frequent and continuing contact between the child and both parents, so long as such contact promotes the child’s welfare.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, G.L. c. 209C, § 20 authorizes modification of a custody or visitation order where such change serves the welfare of the child.

G. L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: This case is a direct-appeal divorce and removal decision, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The court applies the statutory and common‑law ‘best interests of the child’ and ‘real advantage’ standards for an initial removal/custody determination, and does not discuss or require a showing of a material change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about the standard for modification of an existing custody judgment.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on the “cause shown” / best interests standard when parents share joint legal and physical custody. The opinion does not discuss the general standard for modification of prior custody judgments, nor does it state that a moving party must show both a material change in circumstances and that modification serves the child’s best interests. The only reference to “substantial change in circumstances” appears in a block quote from the ALI Principles, not as a Massachusetts rule for modification generally, and the court does not adopt or apply it as such.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)... state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]...
“(4)... If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility for the child, the court should modify the plan... in accordance with the child’s best interests, taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts stress that the best interests of the child are paramount and that increasing a fit parent’s parenting time, where circumstances allow, supports the child’s emotional and psychological welfare. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 840–841.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion does strongly reaffirm that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in custody matters, but it does not stand for the more specific proposition that courts emphasize increasing a fit parent’s parenting time as affirmatively supporting the child’s emotional and psychological welfare. At the cited pages, the court discusses the historical and statutory centrality of the best‑interests standard and the value of stability and continuity with a primary caregiver, not any general preference for expanding a fit parent’s time. Thus, the case partially supports the ‘paramount best interests’ aspect but not the ‘increasing parenting time where circumstances allow’ component of the proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)… ‘the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’….”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The law requires custody and parenting-time orders to evolve as the child’s circumstances and welfare evolve. See Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case focuses on the statutory requirement under G.L. c. 208, § 28 that a custody modification must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and be necessary for the child’s best interests. It does not articulate a broader principle that custody and parenting-time orders must affirmatively ‘evolve’ as the child’s circumstances and welfare evolve; rather, it stresses the need for compelling reasons and material changes before altering existing custody. Thus, citing Rosenthal for a general requirement that orders must evolve over time overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: This opinion is a divorce/property division and custody case, not a modification case. The only relevant portion is where the SJC holds that any future change in custody must proceed by complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does not articulate the standard for granting such a modification (i.e., material change plus best interests). Therefore, it does not support the specific two-part modification standard claimed in the proposition.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: Rolde v. Rolde is an initial divorce and custody judgment, not a modification proceeding. The opinion discusses the best interests of the children as the controlling standard for the original custody determination, but it does not address any requirement that a moving party show a material change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the two-prong modification standard stated in the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: Hunter v. Rose is a custody and parentage case, not a post-judgment modification case. The opinion discusses the best interests of the child standard for an initial custody determination, but it does not address the requirements for modifying an existing custody judgment, nor does it articulate the two-prong "material change in circumstances" plus "best interests" standard. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about what a moving party must show on a modification request.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’” (463 Mass. at 494).

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (rescript)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is about an initial custody determination in a divorce, not about a complaint for modification of a prior custody judgment. It discusses the governing standard as the welfare/best interests of the child, but nowhere mentions (or applies) the requirement of showing a material change in circumstances since an earlier judgment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the two-part ‘material change plus best interests’ standard for modification proceedings.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.raw_text: Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984)
Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly affirmed that the moving party must show both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that modification will serve the best interests of the child. See:
Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.support_reasoning: This case is a care and protection appeal about initial custody and dispositional orders, not a post-judgment modification proceeding. The opinion discusses parental fitness and best interests, and criticizes the lack of detailed findings on placement, but it does not address or articulate any requirement that a moving party show a material change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the two-prong modification standard described in the proposition.
Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.relevant_excerpt: "This court has said that the 'parental fitness' test and the 'best interests of the child' test are not mutually exclusive, but rather 'reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.' ... In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests and issued more than a broad dispositional order committing them to the permanent custody of the department."
